I have a little web app that lets you view an RSS feed in JSON. Turns out can be pretty useful when you just want to see what's in a feed, independent of how the developer formatted it. Here's an example of it viewing my feed. [link]

@ChrisHardie I know it's been tried before, I was one of the people who tried it, but there are reasons to think it will work better in 2022 than it did ten or more years ago. I wrote a piece about this -- [link] I think you'll find it interesting.

@pploug i go skiing a few times every year, for enjoyment and exercise, and just because i like it.

i don't try to make money skiing. 

in fact i spend a lot of money to go skiing.

and yet a few people out there do make their living by skiing.

@pploug it's a really awful thing the tech industry does. it just rips everything up to squeeze a few bucks out of something good and leaves nothing behind that's of any use. 

look at the mess spotify has already made with rogan, and that's just the beginning.
@pploug this is the usual trap -- podcasting doesn't owe you a living, or anyone else.
U.S. must set deadlines and terms for Russia to pull back from Ukraine. [link]

@pploug the important thing is there's no one who gets to say a podcast can't go out. look at the mess spotify got in with rogan. a few more of those and all of a sudden spotify has to vet every podcast. 

not hard to see how vastly different that is from what podcasting is now.
@pploug thanks. ;-)

@pploug okay i take your word. i've had a lot of contact with people from big companies trying to take over open formats, the people generally are repping their companies. not sure how that works, exactly, but they never speak against the interest of their company i've noticed.

@pploug in any case the way you phrased it made it hard to say the poor little podcaster doesn't deserve to still call themselves a podcaster, except when you realize they're  being paid a lot of money to siphon value created in an open ecosystem for themselves, like your company does.
@ashevat no -- getting it from the web interface, but it's gone now. i think it was a glitch on their end.

I'm getting a "rate limit exceeded" error from Twitter, wondering if this is due to something I'm doing, or a problem with the Twitter system. [link]

He works at Spotify and I guess this represents their defense of usurping the term "podcasts." But this is no different from anything else. I was a blogger when I became a contributing editor at Wired. My role changes, it works differently. [link]
@pploug yes, that's correct.
@trvr @amszmidt Gotcha. Radio UserLand ran on Mac and Windows.
@pploug yes, that's correct. you fully understand the issue.

@trvr @amszmidt what's the significance of that copyright date?

it wasn't the first podcast player -- that was Radio UserLand in early 2001.

@trvr @amszmidt I don't like to argue on twitter, but just want to point out that spotify's radio programs are not mp3s and are not delivered in an rss feed, and you would not be able to listen to them on a sandisk clip.

If the open web had a good lawyer we could stop Spotify from calling their radio programs "podcasts" because it's a fraudulent claim. 

It's like saying a car gets 800 miles per gallon when it gets 30 mpg. It's a lie. People expect podcasts to work in any player. Spotify is lying
Why we should take care of podcasting before we lose it. [link]

@danshipper -- I read your piece about Roam, and I've been curious about the product since I heard people loving the linking it has. I played around with the ideas in my own product, Drummer -- and came to the same conclusion you did.

I went further and implemented a search facility and loaded in about a decade worth of blog posts to it. I love it. Google's search has been degrading for years, but it was never as good as my dedicated search. Here's an example search. [link]

I've been working on outliners for a long time, and I like the direction #toolsforthought has been pulling me. 

I think search is the answer. You shouldn't have to plan in advance for what will be easily findable in the future. You very often have no idea what will be important.
Another search. [link]

In Frontier we have two verbs that can be used to normalize the formatting of XML files. They are:

xml.compile (xmltext) returns xstruct

xml.decompile (xstruct) returns xmltext

Is there the equivalent in Node.js?
@awbjs thanks! i was kind of surprised how well the pieces fit together now. also servers are a lot cheaper and higher performance, so more is possible there too.

I organized my thinking about Twitter and RSS in this blog post. The environment is very different today from the one the last time Twitter had RSS support. And we can do *all* this with the existing Twitter API. Important point. No waiting. [link]

### I am tweeting via RSS

This is a thread that will turn into a longish element in my RSS feed of tweets.

Somewhere in the middle of this thread I will provide the URL of the feed.
I'm using GitHub to store the RSS feed, because GitHub has a bunch of very sophisticated notification services that I think might add to the RSS experience.
It might even make the RSS world-of-tweets perform at the scale of [link]? Certainly better than any server I could deploy. ;-)
RSS definitely could use another look given the reality of  server cost and performance of 2022. Last time we did this work was maybe 15 years ago?

### Another test

I have the feed working, I think.

This will test that. 

If it works, I will see this as a titled item in my RSS reader. The title will be "Another test".

Each of the paragraphs will be enclosed in an HTML paragraph element.

Here goes nothing! ðŸ™ðŸ½
And this is what that tweet looks like in the feed. Check it out -- it has a title! That's new. [link]

### Markdown document titles

I'm pretty sure Markdown does not have the concept of the title of a document.

But titles are important. RSS has the concept of a title because many blog posts have titles.

### cont'd

Tweets don't have titles, but they could.

And that would make the match betw Twitter and RSS work, where the last time it was tried it didn't.

I believe this was the reason it didn't work.

### cont'd

Also I think I just figured out how to hook up threads to RSS feed items that are longer than 280 chars.

Why didn't I figure this out sooner?
